name: lignite mine operation | lignite | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9928/documentation

This datasets represents the production of 1 kg lignite with an energy content of 9.9 MJ/kg pit coal. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for operation. Additionally, 10 years of life time are taken into account due to the recultivation of land after operation. Land use is considered in this dataset. Data regarding land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas have been estimated. Land use for affected water supply areas only represent rough estimations. Data regarding land use are not valid for specific regions, for this, higher uncertainties are considered. In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 10^11 kg is assumed. This figure represents an average value and is not representative for single mines or specific conditions.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Mining process starting from brown coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg lignite at the lignite mine. This datasets includes land recultivation after operation, emissions into water and air, water extraction during pumping, energy requirements for operation as well as the deposition of spoil. This dataset doesn’t include heat requirements (provided by coal or oil) due to the fact that heat is often derived from mine-mouth power plants. Noise emissions and steam are also not included, however significant noise emissions and steam amounts are assumed. Furthermore, this dataset doesn't include emissions to groundwater.

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Average European conditions around the beginning of the 1990s.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In opencast mines it is possible to mine lignite up to a depth of 600 meters, usually mines can reach a depth less than 200 meters. The process of opencast lignite mining is simple and varies little.Two to six times the amount of lignite is mined as spoil during lignite mine operation.;;Originally bucket-chain dredgers were used, which from its design principle are constructed as building site dredgers, but from its capacity they represent large machines with a spoil mining capacity of about 40 Mio m3/a. Nowadays, conveyor bridges are used in mining areas with smaller depths (up to 60 meteres) and intact, mostly horizontal seams. With conveyor bridges spoil is mined at the borehole top and backfilled at the tail immediately. Conveyor bridges show lengths between 200 and 600 meters and are able to mine up to 130 Mio m3 spoil per year. Stope mining is used for mining areas with greater depths or with difficult geological conditions. Stope mining represents a system with bucket-wheel excavator, conveyor and stacker where the overburden is removed stepwise. With the bucket-wheel excavator spoil is mined, which then is transported to the stacker over long distances. The stacker is very important for land recultivation and landscaping. Recultivation and landscaping is only partially possible with conveyor bridges. However, conveyor bridges are three times cheaper and energy-saving than stope mining. Therefore conveyor bridges are used wherever possible. ;;Due to the difficult geological conditions and partially hard overburden, in Ptolemais, Greece (Gross 1988) systems with power shovel, crusher, tripper car and power shovel/lorry are used.;;Depending on the system coal is transported to mine-mouth power plants or converting factories by conveyors, trains or lorries. In Germany, coal is not treated. In Greece, coal is pre-dried before combustion in mine-mouth power plants to increase the low heat value (below 5 MJ/kg). No information about treatment in Spain or former Yugoslavia was available. ;;References:;Steinmetz R. (1992) Schematische Gegenüberstellung von Schaufelrad¬bagger/ Band/ -Absetzer- Betrieb und Förderbrückenbetrieb bei der Abraumgewinnung und -verkippung in Braunkohletagebauen In: Braunkohle3/92 s.5-7.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. At opencast mines coal output amounts to 95 % (CERI 1976) and is assumed to be even higher when taking massive seams into account. It is further assumed that mining underground slightly decreases the output ratio. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value hast to be calculated. 

Two third of open pit lignite is mined in Germany, the rest is predominantly mined in Greece, former Yugoslavia and Spain. Only 6 % of lignite is mined underground. It has to be considered that this information is based on uncertain values and the results are hardly changed. Thus, in the dataset this is included via rounding up/off the figures for opencast mining accordingly. 

The energy content of lignite amounts to 9.9 MJ/kg pit coal and is estimated based on the average of gross calorific values for all different mining regions. Due to averaging the Cumulative Energy Demand differs from actual values.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Due to the lack of information a rough estimation of emissions to water is made. For mining regions outside Germany (6 m3/t) a water elevation of 1 m3/t is assumed. In general a salinity degree of 1 g/l is estimated. According to Euler this figure represents an assumption and is likely to be higher; no differentiation between different kinds of salt was made. Furthermore it was assumed that 40 kg pyrite (FeS2) per ton pit coal are worn in overburden and are released untreated with ground water as Fe2+ and SO42-  into the discharge system. These are very rough estimations and are not based on literature sources but shall be included in the dataset. The potential effects of lowering the pH-value and leaching of micronutrients are not included in the dataset.

Estimation. In this dataset data regarding transformation of land (from unspecified to mineral extraction) is based on RWTH. In this literature source no differentiation between operational areas, extraction areas and dump areas was made. 

Based on the share of opencast mines and average seam thickness primary land use can be estimated. Regarding lignite mining primary land use amounts to 0.037 m2 /t pit coal. No classification of former utilization classes was possible. According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.

Estimation. Radon emissions arise out of the release of coal and overburden. If the overburden is loose (e.g. Rheinland) emissions during mining are low, because the gas release already happened. About 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. These figures are assumed to be valid for hard coal and could be lower for lignite. In the UCTE-area most of lignite is mined in seams with loose overburden. Thus, in this dataset it is assumed that one quarter of these emissions are emitted, which corresponds to 3 Bq/kg coal.

Estimation. To calculate energy consumption, requirements for operating energy and the extracted amounts and qualities are necessary to calculate weighted average values. Data is based on old literature sources and estimations; partially CENTREL-countries are not considered. Based on a long time constant in this sector, the influence on the outcome is assumed to be low. 

Distinctions between mine spoils and water amount and the use of diesel-powered machinery and lorries are included. Emission factors per MJ diesel for lorries and construction machinery are quite similar, thus it is assumed that the total amount of diesel is used for construction machinery. 

Further references:

exchanges.description: Estimation. Due to the high water content, lignite has low dust emissions, compared to the overburden where high dust emissions can be expected. Barriers, green areas and water sprinklers are installed to avoid high dust emissions. A large part of emissions remain in the opencast mine and is deposited within the mining region. However, fine particles are emitted and result in dust exposure in the near surroundings. To estimate dust emissions for the UCTE-region a mining region with a diameter of 4 km and an annual mining output of 15 Mio. t are assumed. At the edge of the area 0,2 g/(m2*d) emissions and at a distance of 3 km 0.1 g/(m2*d) are assumed to be measured. At a distance of 6 km emissions are assumed to be insignificant. According to these assumptions annual dust emissions of 0,4 kg/t lignite are estimated. In UBA for lignite treatment 0,2 kg/t lignite during distribution and transport are estimated. In this dataset the previous approach is used because it can be assumed that total emissions in Europe are two times higher than the figures given in UBA.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. To calculate energy consumption, requirements for operating energy and the extracted amounts and qualities are necessary to calculate weighted average values. Data is based on old literature sources and estimations;  partially CENTREL-countries are not considered. Based on a long time constant in this sector, the influence on the outcome is assumed to be low. 

Due to the fact that most of the mining machines and also heat pumps are powered by electricity, significant amounts of electricity are consumed which is partly produced in mine-mouth power plants. Distinctions between mine spoils and water amount and the use of diesel-powered machinery and lorries are included. The weighted average electricity consumption (UCTE-mix) is assumed to be twice the amount for the operation of an opencast mine. 

Electricity is often derived from mine-mouth power plants. Lignite is commonly used to produce electricity close to the mine, thus electricity generation of the power plant is much higher than station supply. In this dataset it was assumed that electricity is sourced from the grid and that the UCTE mix is used. The assumptions are based on the following facts: mine-mouth power plants often feed electricity in the public grid; in case of hard coal mining mine-mouth power plants are not operated all-the-year; data for the calculation of a representative mine-mouth power plant were incomplete. High voltage electricity is used, so that transmission losses and little grid efforts can be represented in the best possible way. 

Further references:

Arbeitsgruppe Energiebilanzen (1991) Energiebilanz der Bundesrepublik Deutschland für das Jahr 1990. Essen, Deutschland. 

DGMK-Arbeitskreis (1992) Ansatzpunkte und Potentiale zur Minderung des Treibhauseffektes aus Sicht der fossilen Energieträger. Hamburg.

Hojdar J., Klimecky O. (1992) Braunkohle in der CSFR. In: Neue Bergbau­technik, 22. Jg., Heft 9/10, 1992, s.358-364.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Based on the share of opencast mines and average seam thickness primary land use can be estimated. Regarding lignite mining primary land use amounts to 0.037 m2 /t pit coal. No classification of former utilization classes was possible. According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.

Land reclamation is considered with an additional useful life time of 10 years. After operation it is assumed that the land is predominantly used as agricultural land. Furthermore it is assumed that the time between operation and agricultural land use can be neglected. However in OECD 1985 it is said that mainly outside Europe land is not recultivated due to high costs. Due to the fact that European conditions are considered in the dataset, a transformation of land into agricultural land after 30 years of use is taken into account.

Estimation. Based on the share of opencast mines and average seam thickness primary land use can be estimated. Regarding lignite mining primary land use amounts to 0.037 m2 /t pit coal. No classification of former utilization classes was possible. According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.

Total affected land is considered in the dataset with a value of 1.03 m2 /t.

Estimation. To calculate the energy balance of resource consumption the gross calorific value is an important figure. The gross calorific value depends on the quality of brown coal and is about 1 to 2 MJ/kg above the net calorific value. Due to the fact that predominantly soft brown coal is mined an additional value of 1,1 MJ/kg can be assumed, which corresponds to 13 % of the net calorific value. 

The energy content of lignite amounts to 9.9 MJ/kg pit coal and is estimated based on the average of gross calorific values for all different mining regions.  Due to averaging the Cumulative Energy Demand differs from actual values.

Estimation. Spoil in a mining plant is defined as overburden which is continuously deposited in the opencast mine. Due to the fact that land use and emissions to water of overburden is considered at coal extraction, overburden is not included as by-product in this dataset. An amount of overburden of 3.7 m3/t pit coal respectively 7 t/t pit coal (approx. 2700 t/TJel) can be estimated.

Estimation. In this dataset 0,34 m3/t respectively 0,23 kg/t methane emissions are assumed. These emissions are not completely emitted during the mining process. Further emissions are assumed during transport, storage and homogenization. In this dataset no distinction between the different processes is made. In energy terms methane emissions lead to a loss of 10 MJ/t respectively 0,1 % of net calorific value. The average net calorific value of a ton usable output is 8,8 MJ/kg for opencast mining and 13.5 MJ/kg for underground mining. Based on these figures an average net calorific value of 8 MJ/kg for lignite in UCTE-regions can be estimated.
